questions.text: Which of the following is true about the heart rate in idioventricular rhythm?
questions.solution:
A heart rate of less than 40 beats/minute is consistent with idioventricular rhythm. 

Idioventricular rhythm occurs when both the sinoatrial node (SAN) and atrioventricular node (AVN) do not function. This leads to the Purkinje system taking over as a pacemaker to ensure ventricular contraction. The rate is usually less than 40 beats/minute. 

Causes of idioventricular rhythm include electrolyte abnormalities, digitoxin toxicity, anesthetic agents, cocaine, and isoprenaline. 

The usual findings of idioventricular rhythm include a heart rate of fewer than 40 beats per minute. The ECG may or may not have P waves. If there is a complete AVN block leading to sinus rhythm with idioventricular escape rhythm it will have P waves. Idioventricular rhythm without P waves is of poor prognosis. This usually proceeds a flat line. 

Other options: 

Option A - A heart rate of more than 300 beats/minute is seen in atrial flutter.

Option C - A heart rate of 50 - 100 beats per minute is seen in normal sinus rhythm and accelerated idioventricular rhythm.

Option A - A heart rate of more than 100 beats/ minute is seen in sinus tachycardia and non-sustained ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presents with palpitations, chest pain, and dizziness. Her heart rate is 135 beats/ minute. Her ECG strip is shown below. Which of the following treatment modalities is recommended for definitive treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the ECG finding with delta waves suggest a diagnosis of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). The recommended treatment modality is radiofrequency catheter ablation of the accessory pathway. 

Wolf Parkinson White (WPW) is a type of preexcitation syndrome, i.e., abnormally early ventricular excitation, which in WPW, occurs via a bypass tract (Bundle of Kent). Normally, there is a normal AV nodal delay to allow adequate ventricular filling. The bypass tract allows impulses to skip the nodal delay leading to preexcitation of the ventricles. In this syndrome, there is both preexcitation and delayed conduction leading to a shortened PR interval (< 0.12 secs) and wide QRS. There is a characteristic delta wave notch in the QRS wave as seen in the picture.

Patients with WPW may be asymptomatic or have multiple recurrent arrhythmias with chest pain, dizziness, or sudden cardiac arrest. The initial treatment of WPW involves vagal manoeuvres to abort the tachycardia. Pharmacologic therapy with adenosine, verapamil, or beta-blockers can be administered. However, as recurrent arrhythmias may lead to AF, radiofrequency catheter ablation of the accessory pathway is advised for definitive treatment.

Other options: 

Option A: Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator is not used to treat WPW. Ablation has a better prognosis. 

Options B and D: Percutaneous coronary intervention and coronary artery bypass grafting are done in patients who have had a myocardial infarction.

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with severe retrosternal chest pain, sweating, and breathlessness for the last 20 minutes. His ECG is shown below. Which of the following treatment options is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
The ECG with ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF is suggestive of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. The treatment option most appropriate for this patient is percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).

Myocardial infarction (MI) occurs when there is an occlusion of one or more arteries supplying the heart. This leads to an imbalance between myocardial oxygen demand and supply, leading to myocardial ischemia and death. 

Treatment of MI primarily involves control of discomfort, fibrinolysis, and reperfusion therapy. Reperfusion therapy includes both PCI and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). 

In PCI, a stent or balloon is inserted into the occluded artery to restore blood flow. It is done under local anesthesia and mild sedation. In CABG, a vessel is grafted from a different part of the body and is used to restore blood flow by bypassing the occlusion. It is a surgical procedure. CABG is generally preferred for severe left main and three-vessel disease. 

Reperfusion therapy should be done as soon as possible, within a few hours of the onset of symptoms. It has better short-term and long-term outcomes when compared to fibrinolysis alone. 

Other options: 

Option A - Aspirin and ibuprofen are given to patients with acute pericarditis. 

Option B - Cardioversion is done in patients with atrial fibrillation.

Option D - Coronary artery bypass grafting is preferred in patients with severe multivessel disease. 

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

Related Pearl: Indications for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG)

Class I indications for CABG from the American College of Cardiology(ACC) and American Heart Association(AHA).

  • Left main disease
  • Three-vessel disease with or without proximal LAD disease
  • Two vessel disease with proximal LAD disease
  • Survivors of sudden cardiac death with presumed ischemia-mediated VT  

Other indications for CABG include the following:

  • Disabling angina
  • Ongoing ischemia in the setting of a non–ST-segment elevation (MI) that is unresponsive to medical therapy
  • Poor LV function but with viable, nonfunctioning myocardium above the anatomic defect that can be revascularized

questions.text: The ECG of a 62-year-old hypertensive patient is as given below. What does his ECG show?
questions.solution:
His ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). 

In this patient, the height of the S wave in V1 is 25 and the R wave in V5 is 21. The sum of the two is 46. 

ECG findings suggestive of LVH are as follows: 

  • SV1 + [RV5 or RV6] >35mm
  • RaVL + SV3 >20 mm in women and >28 mm in men
  • ST depression with T wave inversion 

The causes of LVH can be divided into pressure overload or volume overload. Examples of pressure overload are hypertension and aortic stenosis leading to concentric hypertrophy. Volume overload can occur due to valvular regurgitation leading to ventricular dilation. 

Pathological cardiac conditions leading to increased cardiac workload result in compensatory mechanisms to maintain perfusion and arterial pressure. They include increasing contractility and stroke volume (Frank-Starling law), activation of neurohormonal systems like the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, and release of hormones like norepinephrine and atrial natriuretic peptide. Myocardial adaptations can also occur resulting in cellular hypertrophy of the myocytes. 

LVH occurs due to increased mechanical work. However, the increased muscle mass has increased metabolic demands as well leading to a further increase in oxygen demand. This makes patients with LVH susceptible to ischemia and heart failure. 

Other options:

Option B - Right ventricular hypertrophy is characterized by tall R waves in lead V1, where R is bigger than the S wave, right axis deviation. ST depression and T wave inversion in right to mid-precordial leads can be present.

Option C - Acute myocardial infarction is characterized by localized ST-segment depressions or elevations with T-wave inversions. 

Option D - Acute pericarditis is characterized by widespread ST-segment elevations and T-wave inversions. 

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: A 57-year-old unresponsive male patient is brought to the hospital. He is pulseless and is not breathing. His lead II ECG rhythm strip is shown in the image below. What is the treatment for the given ECG abnormality?
questions.solution:
The ECG with no identifiable P wave, QRS complexes, and irregular rhythm is ventricular fibrillation (VF) and the treatment is defibrillation. 

Ventricular fibrillation is a disorganized ventricular rhythm. In a heart with ventricular fibrillation, there is little to no cardiac output as there is irregular cardiac contraction. In patients outside the hospital, sustained ventricular tachycardias are a common cause leading to ventricular fibrillation.

VF is a shockable rhythm. Thus, defibrillation must be performed in order to restore normal sinus rhythm according to advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) guidelines. In defibrillation, an electrical current is passed into the myocardium which 'resets' it by converting the dysrhythmia into a normal sinus rhythm. 

When the timing of electric current is adjusted according to the R waves or the QRS complex of the cardiac cycle, it is known as synchronized shock, which is administered in cardioversion. In ventricular fibrillation, because of irregular cardiac electrical activity, there are no R waves or QRS complexes to which the cardioversion can be synchronized. Hence, it is administered unsynchronized to the cardiac cycle.

 

Other options:

Option A - Magnesium sulfate is used to treat torsades de points. It is a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. 

Options C and D - Synchronised cardioversion and rate control are used to treat atrial fibrillation (AF). AF has normal QRS complexes with variable atrial activity resulting in irregular P waves of varying morphology.

The below ECG depicts atrial fibrillation:

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below.

questions.text: ECG changes in which of the following leads is consistent with a lateral wall myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
ECG changes in I, aVL, V5, V6 are consistent with lateral wall myocardial infarction.

Myocardial infarction (MI) occurs when there is severe cardiac muscle ischemia. Severe, acute ischemia causes a change in the membrane potential which shortens the duration of the action potential. This creates a voltage gradient between the normal myocardium and ischemic myocardium causing a flow of current between the two. 

This altered flow of current manifests as changes in the ST segment, which represents ventricle repolarization. The change in the ST segment depends on the part of the myocardium involved. If it is confined to the endocardium, it results in ST-segment depression as the ST segment shifts towards the ventricle. If the ischemia is transmural, the ST segment is elevated. There are also hyperacute T waves. This is because the ST vector shifts towards the outer layers. 

The ECG leads are position-specific and thus ST-segment changes in certain leads can help us localize the infarction. 

Lead Location
Standard leads  
II, III, aVF Inferior wall  
V1 - V4 Anterior wall  
I, aVL, V5, V6 Lateral wall
Non-standard leads  
V1R - V6R Right ventricle
V7 - V9 Posterior wall

Other options: 

Option A - Changes in V1 - V4 are seen in anterior wall MIs.

Option C - Changes in II, III, and aVF are seen in inferior wall MIs.

Option D - Changes in V7 - V9 are seen in posterior wall MIs. This is often missed as the standard ECGs do not have leads V7-V9. 

Related Pearl: Cardiac Biomarkers

  Time to initial elevation Mean time to peak elevation Time to return to normal range
Myoglobin 1- 4 h 12 h 24 h
CK-MB 4-8 h 24 h 48-72 h
cTnI 3-12 h 24 h 7-10 d
cTnT 3-12 h 12h – 2d 7-10 d 

CK-MB: Creatine kinase-MB; CTnI: Cardiac-specific troponin I; CTnT: Cardiac-specific troponin T 

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient is assessed with an ECG during his wellness check-up visit. Calculate the heart rate from the ECG given below.
questions.solution:
The RR interval has 19 small boxes in between, and hence the heart rate is 1500/19~79/min.

The relationship between the heart rate and the RR interval is given by: 

Heart rate = 1500/(number of small boxes in between successive R waves) 

Methods to calculate heart rate from ECG: 

Box counting methods: This can be done via the number of small boxes or the large boxes between two successive R waves. If using the large boxes, the equation is  

Heart rate = 300/(number of large boxes in between successive R waves) 

QRS counting methods: This is used when the heart rate is irregular. Thus there will be a variability in the RR intervals, making the box-counting method unreliable. Here, the number of QRS intervals in a set interval, for example, 10 seconds, is counted. This number is then multiplied by an appropriate factor to get an estimate for 60s. In this example, we would multiple the number of QRS complexes in 10s by 6. 

Tachycardia is defined as a heart rate of more than 100 beats/minute and bradycardia is defined as a heart rate of less than 60 beats/minute. 

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: The ECG given below shows:

choices.text: A prolonged PR interval measuring 240 ms
A normal PR interval measuring 240 ms
A prolonged PR interval measuring 160 ms
A normal PR interval measuring 160 ms

questions.solution:
The given ECG shows a prolonged PR interval measuring 240 msec.

The given ECG shows a PR interval measuring 6 small boxes. One small box represents 0.04 sec. Therefore, 6 boxes is 6*0.04 sec = 0.240 sec or 240 msec. 

The PR interval is measured from the beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex. The normal PR interval is 120-200ms.

The image below represents the PR interval:

 

A prolonged PR interval occurs due to a delay in the conduction of electrical impulses from the atria to the ventricles. It is also termed a first-degree heart (AV) block. It is important to note that there is no interruption in conduction. 

People with first-degree AV block are generally asymptomatic and do not require any intervention.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to the clinic with complaints of palpitations. He is diagnosed with tachyarrhythmia. He is started on a drug that resolves his arrhythmia. ECG taken 3 days after starting medication appears as below, with QTc = 477 ms. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?

 QTc: corrected QT interval
questions.solution:
The patient has a QTc of 477 ms which indicates QT prolongation on taking the drug (normal QT- < 440 ms in males). Among the given options, QT prolongation is seen with procainamide, a Class 1A anti-arrhythmic drug.

A QT interval is slowed by a decreased heart rate. A QTc (corrected QT interval) is calculated as QT/√RR, to remove the effect of HR. Normal QTc is about 440 ms. Values of more than 440 ms in males and 450 ms in females are considered to be prolonged.

A QT prolongation can present as syncope or cardiac arrest. Prompt intravenous administration of 1-2mg magnesium sulfate is needed. It gives time to correct electrolyte imbalances and remove the offending agent.

Other anti-arrhythmic drugs associated with QT prolongation i.e (Class 1A and Class 3):

  • Sotalol
  • Amiodarone
  • Quinidine
  • Procainamide
  • Dofetilide
  • Ibutilide

Related Pearl: Drugs causing QT prolongation and torsades de pointes

Drugs Associated with QT Prolongation and Torsades de Pointes:

Antiarrhythmics:

  • Sotalol
  • Amiodarone
  • Quinidine
  • Procainamide
  • Dofetilide
  • Ibutilide

Antimicrobials:

  • Levofloxacin
  • Ciprofloxacin
  • Gatifloxacin
  • Moxifloxacin
  • Clarithromycin
  • Erythromycin
  • Ketoconazole
  • Itraconazole
  • Rilpivirine

Antidepressants:

  • Amitriptyline
  • Desipramine
  • Imipramine
  • Doxepin
  • Fluoxetine
  • Sertraline
  • Venlafaxine

Antipsychotics:

  • Haloperidol
  • Droperidol
  • Quetiapine
  • Ziprasidone
  • Thioridazine

Others:

  • Cisapride
  • Sumatriptan
  • Zolmitriptan
  • Arsenic
  • Dolasetron
  • Methadone
     

Related Pearl: Anti-arrhythmic drugs

Class of antiarrhythmic drugs

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are correct with respect to the cardiac cycle, heart sounds, and the waveforms seen on the ECG?

1) Timing of S1 heart sound corresponds temporally to the occurrence of QRS wave in ECG

2) Timing of S2 heart sound corresponds temporally to the end of T wave in ECG

3) 'v' wave of JVP mirrors the rise in atrial pressure before the tricuspid valve opens

4) The ‘c’ wave of JVP is seen during the first phase of the ventricular diastole.
questions.solution:
The statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct.

As clear from Wigger's diagram below, S1 corresponds the timing of S1 heart sound corresponds temporally to the occurrence of QRS wave in ECG.

Similarly, the timing of the S2 heart sound corresponds to the end of the T wave in ECG. 

The statement D is incorrect as the ‘c’ wave of JVP is seen during the isovolumetric contraction (with all valves closed) phase when the ventricular muscle continues to contract. 

The Cardiac Cycle:

Diastole 

  • Protodiastole
    Before the semilunar valve closes, even though ventricular muscle is relaxed, blood flow into great vessels is due to the momentum of blood.
  • Iso-volumetric Relaxation
    The ventricular muscle continues to relax, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.
  • Ventricular Filling
    Isovolumetric relaxation ends when the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial pressure and the AV valves open, permitting the ventricles to fill.
  • Atrial Systole
    During the last third of diastole, the atria contract and give additional thrust to the inflow of blood into the ventricles. It correlates with the 'a' wave in JVP.

Systole 

  • Isovolumetric Contraction
    The ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed. 
    It correlates with the ‘c’ wave of JVP.
  • Ventricular Ejection
    When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the valves open, and ventricular ejection begins. Peak pressures in the left and right ventricles are about 120 and 25 mmHg, respectively. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

Related Pearl: Heart sounds

Heart Sound

Frequency

Duration

Associated Event

ECG Correlation

S1

25-45 Hz

0.15 sec

Closure of AV Valves-Onset of Ventricular systole

Later half of R wave

S2

50 Hz

0.12 sec

Closure of Semilunar Valves-Onset of ventricular diastole

Later half of T wave

S3

Low

0.1 sec

First rapid filling phase of ventricular diastole

Between the T and P wave

S4

Below 20 Hz

0.1 sec

Last rapid filling phase of ventricular diastole due to atrial contraction

Following P wave

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with unresponsiveness, no breathing or palpable pulse. He has the following ECG findings.  Which is the next step of management indicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The next step of management indicated in this patient is chest compression. 

Chest compressions are indicated in patients with asystole and pulseless electrical activity (PEA). PEA refers to any electrical activity on ECG in a patient without a pulse.

This patient presented with cardiac arrest and the ECG shows asystole (flatline/ lack of electrical activity). This is not a shockable rhythm. Management involves the initiation of chest compressions and administering epinephrine. Chest compression should be continued for two minutes, following which pulse is reassessed. If it is still not palpable, chest compressions should be continued again for another two minutes. Epinephrine can be administered every 3-5 minutes.

It is important to confirm asystole on the ECG by monitoring other leads or changing the electrode panels by 90 degrees to look at the electrical activity on a different plane. 

In most cases, asystole is irreversible. 

 

Other options:

Option B - Defibrillation - it is recommended for ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia.

Option C - Cardioversion is recommended for atrial fibrillation with hemodynamic instability and low risk of stroke.

Option D - Adenosine is recommended for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with the abnormality depicted in the given ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows inverted P waves, negative QRS in lead I, and reversal of normal r wave progression. The condition associated with these findings is dextrocardia. 

Dextrocardia is the abnormal position of the heart on the right side of the chest or in the midline. It may be seen as an isolated condition or as a part of situs inversus, where the other organs are also inverted in position. Situs inversus is associated with Kartagener's syndrome (a triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis). 

Findings suggestive of dextrocardia:

  • Inverted P waves in Lead I and aVL
  • Negative QRS complex and T wave in Lead I
  • Lead I: inversion of all complexes, aka ‘global negativity’ i.e. inverted P wave, negative QRS, inverted T wave
  • Reversal of normal r-wave progression across the precordium

Most patients are asymptomatic. Some may present with varying symptoms due to other coexisting congenital diseases. 

Other options:

Option A - Cardiac tamponade would present with reduced amplitude of the QRS complexes and electrical alternans on the ECG.

 

Option B - Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease would present as multifocal atrial tachycardia (variable P wave morphology) and right ventricular hypertrophy on ECG. 

 

Option C - Type 1 Atrioventricular block would have prolonged PR intervals.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a finding you would expect to see in a patient with a left bundle branch block?

choices.text: Broad monophasic R wave in V5-V6

questions.solution:
RSR’ pattern in V1-3 is seen in the case of the right bundle branch block (RBBB), not the left bundle branch block (LBBB). 

ECG findings suggestive of LBBB:

  • QRS duration of >120 ms 
  • Dominant S wave in V1 with loss of R wave
  • Notched R wave and no Q wave in V6

The below image shows the characteristic changes in LBBB:

 

ECG findings suggestive of RBBB:

  • rSR’ pattern in V1-2 
  • Wide S wave in the lateral leads I, V6
  • T wave inversion in the right precordial leads and upright T waves in left precordial leads due to discordance to terminal QRS vector
  • Broad QRS complex of more than > 120 ms

The image below and the ECG show the above mentioned changes in RBBB: 

Bundle branch blocks occur due to impaired conduction in the intraventricular conduction system. This leads to the prolongation of the QRS complex by more than 120 ms. However, incomplete blocks can also occur, leading to a QRS complex duration of 110–120 ms. 

The orientation of the QRS vector depends on the branch block. In LBBB, the QRS vector is directed to the left and posteriorly. In RBBB, the QRS vector is oriented anteriorly and to the right, leading to an rSR' pattern in V1 and qRS in V6. 

RBBBs are more common in patients without structural heart disease. LBBB is associated with coronary heart disease, hypertensive heart disease, aortic valve disease, and cardiomyopathy.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old male patient presents with a heart rate of 45 beats/minute and blood pressure of 70/40 mmHg. According to the ACLS criteria, what is the next best step in the management of this patient?

ACLS - Advanced Cardiac Life Support
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is that of bradycardia and according to the ACLS criteria, the next best step in the management of this patient is the administration of a single dose of atropine. 

Bradycardia is defined as a heart rate of less than 60 beats/ min. Those who present with bradycardia should be first stabilized with the following:

  • Maintain patient airway and breathing
  • Administer oxygen if breathlessness is present
  • Cardiac monitor and blood pressure to be monitored with oximetry
  • IV access to be placed
  • 12 lead ECG done 

Following the initial stabilization, the patient should be checked for hypotension, altered mental status, signs of shock, angina, and acute heart failure. If none are present, then the patient can be monitored. If any of the above are present, then atropine 0.5 mg must be administered. This must be repeated every 3-5 minutes up to a maximum dose of 3mg. Atropine inhibits the muscarinic effects of the parasympathetic nervous system.

If the maximum dose of atropine has been administered and there is no response, then the next step is to initiate one of the following: 

  • Transcutaneous pacing (Option B) OR
  • Dopamine infusion at 5-20 mcg/minute (Option C) OR
  • Epinephrine infusion at 2-10 mcg/minute (Option D)

If the patient is not responding to treatment then expert consultation and transvenous pacing must be done.

Related Pearl: Adult Bradycardia with Pulse Algorithm

When a patient is in bradyarrhythmia typically with a heart rate of <50 bpm the initial intervention consists of identifying and treating the underlying cause. This includes: 

  • Maintaining a patent airway and assisting breathing as necessary
  • Administering oxygen if hypoxemic
  • Attaching cardiac monitor to identify rhythm; monitor blood pressure and oximetry
  • IV access
  • 12-Lead ECG 

If the bradyarrhythmia is persisent causing hemodynamic instability, then the management is as depicted by the flowchart (based on the AHA guidelines) below:

questions.text: A 47-year-old male patient presents with retrosternal chest pain. On auscultation, a pericardial friction rub is present. Echocardiography reveals a small amount of pericardial fluid. The ECG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient with widespread ST elevation is acute pericarditis.

Acute pericarditis is an inflammation of the pericardium characterized by retrosternal chest pain that is aggravated by deep inspiration and supine position and relieved by sitting and leaning forward. It can be attributed to various causes like infections or inflammatory conditions like RA and SLE, or miscellaneous causes like iatrogenic, neoplasms, drugs, etc.

On auscultation, 85% of patients have a pericardial friction rub. This appears as a rough scratching sound at end of expiration when the patient is sitting and leaning forward. 

ECG findings of acute pericarditis need to be differentiated from those of myocardial infarction as they are similar.

There are four stages in the development of acute pericarditis ECG changes.

  • Stage 1: Widespread elevation of ST segments; depression of PR segment below the TP segment
  • Stage 2: ST segments return to normal after a few days
  • Stage 3: T waves become inverted
  • Stage 4: ECG returns to normal after weeks or months

Echocardiography is diagnostic for acute pericarditis. It would reveal a small amount of pericardial fluid. It can also be confirmed by CT or MRI. 

Treatment of acute pericarditis is nonspecific. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are recommended, along with bed rest.

Other options:

Option A - Myocardial infarction would not have a pericardial friction rub. In addition, the ST changes would be localized to a specific area but in pericarditis, there are widespread changes. They would also be more prominent elevations.

Option C - Cardiac tamponade is characterized by Beck's triad of hypotension, jugulo-venous distension, and muffled heart sounds. None of these are present in this patient. 

Option D - Pulmonary embolism would be characterized by tachycardia, inverted T waves (right ventricular overload) in leads V1 - V4, and S1Q3T3 pattern would be seen.

questions.text: In a normal ECG, which among the following leads would show R wave with maximal positive height?
questions.solution:
In a normal ECG, an R wave of maximal positive height is seen in lead V4 or V5. 

The QRS has different morphology across the chest leads because of their position on the chest wall. The relationship between the direction of vectors and the precordial leads determines the height of the R wave. This is characterized by an increase in the height of the R wave from V1 to V6.

Ventricular depolarization consists of two phases of depolarization:  

Interventricular septum-

  • The first phase is a short (< 0.04 s) depolarization of the interventricular septum. It begins with a branch of the bundle of His on the left side of the septum. This causes the vector to go from the left side to the right and anteriorly.  
  • During the first phase, there is a small R wave (positive deflection) in lead V1, gradually altering, across the precordial leads, to a small Q wave (negative deflection) in lead V6.

Ventricular mass- 

  • The second wave involves simultaneous depolarization of both the ventricles. The left ventricle contains more muscle mass so the vector points towards the left and posteriorly.
  • In the second phase, there is a deep S wave (negative deflection) in lead V1, gradually altering to an R wave (positive deflection) in lead V6. 

This changing QRS morphology from lead V1 to V6 is termed R wave progression.

R wave of maximal positive height in lead V4 and V5, as seen in the image below:

 

At a certain point, named the transition zone, the height of the R wave and the S wave are equal. This generally occurs around lead V3 (as seen in the image above) or V4. 

Other options: 

Option B - V1 usually has a small R wave and a deep S wave, termed rS.

Option C - Lead aVR is generally negative with an rS complex, QS complex (no R wave), or a Qr complex. 

Option D - V2 would have a similar appearance to V1 with a slightly larger R wave and a slightly smaller S wave. 

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of ischemic heart disease presents with palpitations for the last 3 days. A transesophageal echo shows a thrombus in the left atrium. His ECG is shown below. Which of the following should be done to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with ECG showing  irregular RR intervals with absent P waves is suggestive of atrial fibrillation. His CHA2DS2-VASc score is 2 (history of ischemic heart disease and age of 70), he is symptomatic for > 48 hours, and there is presence of a left atrial thrombus thus requiring initiation of anticoagulation.  

The major source of thromboembolism and stroke in AF is the formation of thrombus in the left atrial appendage due to stagnant flow. Hence thromboembolism must be prevented by giving anticoagulants, along with an appropriate rate/rhythm control strategy with the help of electrical or pharmacologic cardioversion. 

The treatment of atrial fibrillation depends on three things: the duration of symptoms, the severity of symptoms, and the risk of stroke. The patients who present within 48 hours of the onset of symptoms have a lower risk of an existing atrial thrombus and can be safely cardioverted. Those who present with unknown or known onset of more than 48 hours should ideally be anticoagulated before cardioversion. This can be done in 2 ways as shown below:

The severity of atrial fibrillation refers to the presence of symptoms such as hypotension, pulmonary edema, or angina that are reflective of the cardiac health prior to the onset of fibrillation, and requires emergency cardioversion.

For long-term treatment of patients, the risk of stroke is calculated using the CHA2DS2-VASc score, and anticoagulation is given to those with a score of 1 or more.

Note: Electrical cardioversion is contraindicated in this patient due to the presence of a left atrial thrombus and therefore high risk of stroke.

Related Pearl: CHADS2 VASc Score (Risk of stroke in AF)

RISK FACTOR POINTS
C- Congestive Heart Failure 1
H- Hypertension 1
A2- Age >= 75 years 2
D- Diabetes 1
S2- Prior stroke or TIA 2
V- Vascular disease   1
A- Age 65–74 years  1
Sc- Sex category (Female sex)  1

 

CHA2DS2-VASc Score Stroke rate per 100 Patient Years
0 0
1 1.3
2 2.2
3 3.2
4 4.0
5 6.7
6 9.8
7

9.6
8 6.7
9 15.2

questions.text: A 57-year-old female patient with end-stage kidney disease comes for a follow-up. An ECG is done which is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows tall, peaked T waves and loss of P waves. These findings and the clinical scenario suggest the likely diagnosis of hyperkalemia.

Hyperkalemia is defined as a serum potassium level of more than 5.5 mEq/L. 

Hyperkalemia is a dangerous electrolyte abnormality that can cause drastic conduction changes. It can be diagnosed by a sequence of changes affecting the ST-T segments and QRS complex. ST-T segment changes reflect a change in repolarization while QRS complex changes reflect a change in depolarization.

The ECG changes that can be seen in hyperkalemia depend on the extent of hyperkalemia. 

S. No. Serum potassium level ECG change
1 5.5 - 6.5 mEq/L tall, peaked T waves with 'tented' or 'pinched' shape
2 6.5 - 7.5 mEq/L loss of P waves
3 7.0 - 8.0 mEq/L widened QRS complex
4 > 8.0 mEq/L sine wave

 

The most common cause of hyperkalemia is kidney failure. Drugs that cause hyperkalemia include angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, potassium-sparing diuretics. 

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following:

  1. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective.
  2. Administer regular insulin with dextrose. Insulin reduces the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. Dextrose counteracts the hypoglycemic effects of insulin.
  3. Remove potassium with calcium-based resins, diuretics, or hemodialysis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about pacemakers is correct?

choices.text: A single chamber pacemaker is inserted in the left atrium
A single chamber pacemaker is inserted in the right atrium
A dual-chamber pacemaker is inserted in the left atrium and left ventricle
A dual-chamber pacemaker is inserted in the left atrium and right ventricle

questions.solution:
The statement, a single chamber pacemaker is inserted in the right atrium, is correct. 

Pacemakers are inserted in the right-sided chambers of the heart. 

A single chamber pacemaker is placed in the right atrium OR right ventricle.

Those placed in the right atrium can be used in the treatment of sinoatrial node (SAN) dysfunction when the atrioventricular node (AVN) is functioning properly. However, they are rarely used presently as AVN dysfunction develops with age, making the patients eventually require a dual-chamber pacemaker. 

Those placed in the right ventricle are used in chronic atrial fibrillation with a slow ventricular response. 

Dual-chamber pacemakers are inserted into both the right atrium and right ventricle. This allows normal synchrony or a 'physiologic delay' between atrial and ventricular contraction. 

ECGs of those with pacemakers include a pacing spike. This is a sharp deflection whose amplitude depends on the pacing threshold. The pacing threshold is defined as the minimum amount of energy required to capture the myocardial tissue electrically.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the given ECG?
questions.solution:
The given strip of ECG shows a Wenckebach/Mobitz type I block, a type of second-degree AV block.

In this type of heart block, there is a progressive lengthening of the PR interval with each beat, and then there is a loss of conduction which manifests as a dropped beat. This is characterized by a P wave without a QRS complex. Then the same pattern repeats. The PR interval immediately after a dropped wave is shorter than the PR interval immediately before it.

Types of Heart Block

1. First-degree Heart Block: Prolonged PR interval, > 0.2 s, RR interval equal and constant

 

2. Second-degree Heart Block: missed QRS due to intermitted failure of conduction between the atria and the ventricles.

  • Mobitz type I/ Wenckebach: Progressive prolongation of the PR interval followed by a missed QRS complex.

 

  • Mobitz type II: Fixed PR interval but a QRS wave is missed after every few normally conducted QRS waves.

 

3. Third-degree Heart Block/Complete Heart Block

Here, the atria fail to conduct impulses to the ventricles. This leads to an escape ventricular rhythm. The number of atrial contraction waves (P wave) will be higher than the ventricular contraction waves (R wave). The intervals between two consecutive P waves or R waves will be constant, but there is no relationship between them.
